134.text:
This park is just amazing. Come enjoy the park!😊✌🏻
Love Stanley Park during the daytime. Didn't love the parking fees, but there are so many other options other than cars to get out and enjoy this beautiful place. Try using bus, or bike/walk/jog/skate the sea wall.
Love the lighthouse and look out. Beautiful view of Ocean, North Shore, Lions Gate Bridge, and Vancouver.
Love the miniature train, horse drawn carriage & lots of amazing locations for photography.  📸

If I have one complaint about Stanley Park is that it's busy to get out of the park back through downtown. But that is definitely warranted as it is always absolutely beautiful here. The views of Vancouver and all around the park are always stunning and you could literally spend hours here being active or even just relaxing with your family or friends. Such a wonderful Park to visit

Amazing place to visit with family and friends! You can do a lot of fun activities here and you'll surely love the majestic view of the place. Perfect place to watch the sunset and walk around the area. You'll see people walking, riding their bikes and most of them are watching the views. I highly recommend this place to visit!

Welcome to Stanley Park, Vancouver's first, largest, and most beloved urban park!
Stanley Park is a magnificent green oasis in the midst of the urban landscape of Vancouver.
Explore the 400-hectare natural West Coast rainforest and enjoy scenic views of water, mountains, sky, and majestic trees along Stanley Park's famous Seawall. Discover kilometres of trails, beautiful beaches, local wildlife, great eats, natural, cultural and historical landmarks, along with many other adventures. The park offers a wide range of unforgettable experiences for all ages and interests, including Canada’s largest aquarium.
Vancouver parks are open from 6am to 10pm unless otherwise posted, and access to washrooms is available from dusk until dawn.

￼

Getting here

Walk, bike, take transit, or drive — find simple directions, along with maps to find parking, things to do and see, and trails to explore.

￼

Great place to walk, jog, cycling, picnic and hanging out with friends. One of my most favourite park that I have visited till date. Provide you with a great view of ocean, bridge. Have best Aquarium in Vancouver😍

141.text: I’m just amazed at all the beauty here in Vancouver. Especially with all the fall color. Being from San Diego, we love the ocean, and a chance to walk the sea wall was gorgeous.

Relaxing walks or how ever you want to go around. We usually walk around whole Stanley Park and it is clean with nice views around the city and the ocean. Plentiful of benches to sit and relax the whole 9km.
Whether you are a local or a tourist, I recommend visiting the seawall for a walk, stroll, bike ride, jog, run, etc. all year round.  The fresh air and scenic views are relaxing and therapeutic.

it's a long walk is you would like to do the whole trail, so I recommend to bring a bike or rent one and also much better in the summer. It can be a little chilly down there in the winter months but if you don't mind cold it still is a beautiful spot for a little beach walk.
Closed to bikes due to covid...all biking is done on Stanley park drive (not safe for kids)

150.text: I go here for overcrowded beaches and sunsets.

Great morning! Went for a bike ride around Stanley Park and ended up on Sunset Beach. I would highly recommend this beach and the  surrounding area for either a walk on the various walk ways and paths..or bike ride on either side of False Creek area.
Just down the road u can take a ferry across that will get u to Granville Isand for a selection of nice places to eat. As well there is a winding path way along the water at Granville Island on False Creek that leads youto the end by SCIENCE World. Lots to see and do. A must see for tourists.

Good beach but water is sometimes sus. If you want good water quality for swimming, go to second or third beach. Great for sand or grass activities due to large amounts of FLAT area (no slopes, no tree roots). The roller hockey rink and skateboarding area are great too. Watch for police on bikes looking to poor out alcohol on a warm Friday night.

This is a fantastic park. It's a Vancouver milestone if your asking me. The planetarium close by. Kits beach just off your shoulder. And a great beach, board walk. Gotta love our home!! We are lucky. Let's celebrate that, in a humble and safe way though.

158.text: Before heading to a concert recently I had heard only rumours. The show lived up to every rumour I heard, sound was great, atmosphere was top notch and the show was first class. I would go again and would recommend this venue to anyone looking for a top quality concert.

Been to this venue a few times over the years. It's always been a pleasure. The stage, dance floor and sound are all excellent. I really enjoy the atmosphere and the seating and bar offer good options for those that attend.

Look forward to more shows in the future.

Such a cool place to watch live shows!
Lots of bars to grab drinks and there is both seated options with tables and standing areas so no matter what you’ll have a great time.
Acoustics are okay, definitely could be better sometimes but overall I’ve loved every concert I’ve been to here

Hands down, without a doubt, holding down all 3 podium spots - this venue is the BEST IN VANCOUVER for seeing a show / any kind of live music! Intimate but large enough to feel comfortable (helps having tires in the floor for a little extra bounce too!). From Kid Cudi to Griz, and about a dozen others in between, this place rocks!!

This is one of my absolute favourite venues in Vancouver!! It's intimate enough to get right to the front of the stage and see the sweat flying off the performer, but big enough to find a cozy nook on the top floor to listen to the show in comfort. They even serve food in the early evening! The seating is tiered around the floor so that no matter where you are, you can see the stage (if you choose to sit), but there is no designated seating so one can wonder around where they like. Concerts are just the best here!

241.text: If your body is not ready for a hard hike don't do it.:)))
You should prepare for the hike else it's gonna hurt you

This was the first attraction we went to in Vancouver. We did the Grouse Grind which was both exhausting and incredible! At the top there was a nice restaurant and you can take a ski lift(for free) to get to the highest point where you can see the great views. They also have an owl show and a bear sanctuary. Definitely one of the best attractions in Vancouver. The staff makes it very safe with lots of covid safety policies.

Such a great experience, probably one of the best spot in Vancouver, a combination of sea view and fresh air from the mountain, hiking, skiing, activities, no mater the season, there is always something to do. Whoever you are, no matter the age you are. After a great skiing session, what could be better than a great coffee and a peaceful sunset ?
See you there ☝🏼
H
Ohh man sunset are awesome from that place .....go after 4 get 50 percent discounts and its worth the travel n money

247.text: Beautiful place to visit and things to do year round. So many unique flowers and trees. A little zen paradise nestled in the middle of the city. Family friendly and great for a date night too! Definitely check out the garden maze!
Had a great time walking around and taking in the beauty since the forest fire smoke has taken away the majority of the scenery in Vancouver.

The gardens and the plantlife were absolutely beautiful with plenty of greenery and plants of different varieties, species and colors. It's a very calming and relaxing place to visit with the family or significant other. It's also a very picturesque place with many great photo opportunities for your photo album or social media.

First time to visiting this garden and visiting this light festival. I had a great memory of it. It’s big enough to visit and lots of attractive lights with different styles and types. Anyway, if they could put more effect like big screens of animation would be more attractive~~~

It's a nice park. It's worth visiting. There are so many plants, many plants in many parts of the world, and the design is excellent. When you come to Vancouver, you can recommend it when you have time. You have to clock in every winter. The garden decorated with lights is super beautiful, and it's very suitable to visit with friends and family

252.text: This is a fascinating museum with great tour guides. Tours are free and you should definitely time your visit so you can go on one. It's on the smallish side which means you don't wear yourself out. Fascinating First Nations art, great store and the little cafe was fabulous. Good for all ages!

One visit isn't enough. The building itself is beautiful and there are so many interesting works in this museum. The UBC students are so lucky to come whenever they want for free! I especially enjoyed the first nations exhibits, but the artifacts from other cultures around the world were also beautiful. The juxtaposition of contemporary works with more historical pieces helped to mix things up and avoid information overload from any one time period or place.

The Museum of Anthropology, located on the gorgeous grounds of the University of British Columbia, was a good experience.

Tours may be taken as part of the admission fee. There are wood carvings throughout, including story poles/totem poles on display in various stages of aging. There is a native textile display, and a substantial collection of artifacts from other cultures.

The outdoor grounds and trails are also a great addition to the experience.

There is a snack bar present with various hot drinks and a small selection of sandwiches.

No free parking here. There is a surface lot down the street or a covered parking garage across the street on UBC campus.

Great little museum - kept our girls (3.5, 1) interested for an hour or so. Lots of masks and indigenous art. Interesting Kent Monkman
Exhibit when we went. Relaxed and family friendly: COVID timed-entry meant we were pretty much to ourselves.
Cafe an excellent space to take a short break before heading on.

This facility located on the edge of the University of British Columbia has an absolutely incredible collection of material from First Nation People of the Northwest Coast of British Columbia. If you have interest in history and culture this facility is a must when visiting Vancouver. I would allow an afternoon to visit an absorb the amzing collection at this museum.

255.text:
What a beautiful place to enjoy nature!!
I really liked how quiet it is despite being crowdy!! Go on a weekday and you will find it empty so that you can take a lot of pictures. There is ‘love in the rain’ section in where people attach locks with their lovers name. Also this place has a lake, and really beautiful for walks with your loved ones.
A beautiful place❤️

Edit: went there again and it was just amazing, how beautiful this park is😍

Beautifully sculpted flower gardens - truly an oasis in the city. Grew up playing/rejuvenating here for over 50 years and still marvel at the variety of trees and plants. Excellent foresight to keep this park. Well used, as it should be. Waiting to see what's in that time capsule to be opened in 2054....

This former quarry has been transformed with a lot of thought and care into this tranquil haven. Acknowledgement should be given to former Park Board Deputy Superintendent Bill Livingstone who created this beautiful space for the city of Vancouver and it's visitors to enjoy.
I love the selection of plants that have been chosen, which compliment each other to beautifully and provide our rich tapestry of colours and textures for the eyes to feast on.

Be sure to check out the Conservatory while you are here.
Being on the highest point of Vancouver, there are great city views to be had from the top of thep park. There is also a restaurant which is open throughout the week.

This is a family friendly park to visit.  Plenty of parking, though we prefer to cycle - could do with more bike racks near the conservatory.  Lots of trauls to explore on foot.  There are a couple of naturalized areas which are a lot quieter.  Be careful, outside of the dog off-leash area, many dog owners don't put their did back on a leash.  Tennis courts always seem busy.  To avoid crowds, head to naturalized area by rose garden/pitch n putt, or to the duck pond area, away from the fantastic quarry gardens.

This place is so incredible. I cannot express enough how beautiful and serene this park is. Obviously the best time of year to go is in the summer time, during late July to early August. The landscaping in the botanical gardens is aesthetically pleasing and well maintained. The endless trails you can choose from to walk through the park make it the perfect place to go for a morning jog, a meditating walk or a first date. I have so many fond memories in Queen-E, it is a timeless tourist attraction and a local safe haven for anyone who appreciates flowers and nature. The best part is that it is FREE.

267.text:
Nice beach . Free parking I believe 99.9% sure . I actually slept in my van overnight here spare of moment choice being tired on a long drive. I don’t think I was the only one. Out door shower open 24 hour but toilets do close at night ..
looks like maybe you can have fires on the beach. And the tide is one to be seen. I’ve never seen a tide go so far out
City. Nature. Sea. Sky. Mountain. All in one view. One of my favourite beaches in the city. It can get extremely busy on a sunny day but it’s fairly big and there’s lots of parking

Walked out to the ocean today, about a km. from beach to water's shoreline at low tide. Weather was sunny and warm with a cooling breeze. Great family opportunity! Some people were swimming, as was a dog, and others were playing in the flats making sandcastles, skim boarding on the ponds, and beach combing. The views of the Vancouver skyline, mountains, surf, and ships awaiting entry into the harbour was spectacular. No toys required!

Walking the handy shoreline of Spanish Banks, you suddenly realize this is the quintessential Vancouver experience; taking in the breathtaking skies, cool breeze, and panoramic views of the city that surrounds you: West End, North and West Vancouver, as well as the misty islands that lie beyond, and probably go on forever. Many have come here before you, only to decide to make this cosmopolitan region the stage on which to build their livelihood and home. Languages from all over the world surround you as bits of finely woven conversations drift by, swiftly carried away on endless wind, leaving you to while away the hours, lost in thought, far out on the trembling tidel flats, with one's best friend barking and splashing by your side. Parking fills up fast, so car pool if you can.
Beautiful  Beach ⛱ with great views of  Vancity and the Rocky Mountains ⛰🏔 . Great for picnics and has many tables to accommodate.✌🏾🖖🏾😁

270.text: Lovely park and lake. The trails were nice and even so even I could walk them, despite my weak leg. There are one way signs all over to make it easier to avoid people, which is lovely for covid and also just in general. Beautiful views and almost no garbage. The air was also very crisp. I took a friend from Brazil around on a video tour and she loved it!

Love this gentle trail walk. It's good for beginners if you park downstairs and don't want inclines. You can go the whole way or stick to the right exit you'll find halfway. It'll be a wooden walkway. This takes you back to the beginning. If you want it to be a little harder. Park up on Sperling and walk up the stairs or the hidden Forest trail that takes a scenic route. Check the maps for details and remember it's one way walk following the left side path due to covid. Enjoy you walks!

Deer Lake Park is a beautiful place to escape the hustle and bustle of urban life in Burnaby. It's a lovely natural setting filled with views of the mountains, nature and sounds of singing birds. Excellent trails surrounding the lake and boat rental place near Western parking lot offers kayaks, canoes and paddle boats.
Great to have this park and lake except for goose excrement fouling the beach and picnic areas. Gross.

Deer Lake Park Festival Lawn is probably my favorite music venue in the Lower Mainland. This outdoor  venue is in a beautiful treed setting overlooking a small lake. The lawn is beautifully maintained and always green even during the dry spells. KIDS: Children 10 years and under are free to attend with a supervising adult which gives it a nice family feel. Drinkers and kids are notoriously absent minded and you'll want to pay attention that partiers don't spill beer on your kids. Even in summer, the grass gets damp in the evening... bring something to sit on.
GETTING THERE: The park easily accessible by car, public transit and close to the freeway. There's plenty of free parking at the school for weekend and evening events and it's only a couple of blocks away from the venue. Traffic is usually managed effectively by the local police.
SMOKING: even though this area is deemed as non-smoking, you will find plenty of people lined up in certain areas smoking cigarettes and throughout the entire venue smoking a lot of marijuana. It's best to sit on the west side of the lawn (right side facing the stage) because the wind usually blows eastward and this will protect you from getting out too much smoke in your face.
WASHROOMS: Lots and lots of portable units specifically designated male and female. Normally I don't care whether I have a gender-specific washroom, but when there's a lot of drinking and low light I do appreciate the effort to keep us girls clean.
DRINKING WATER: There's only one drinking station and it's at the back on the right hand (west) side near the washrooms. You may bring an empty water bottle.
FOOD:  There is a limited selection of the usual event type food (and prices) for sale and lineups can be long. No outside food is permitted. I recommend eating at home beforehand. If you accidentally bring food, you can easily eat it outside the venue before you come in still listen to the music while you wait.
BERR: Yes there's beer! In plastic cups with a limit of two per person per purchase. So you can go back and get more if you can afford it.

273.text: It was a beautiful day on the holiday Monday that we went! We were there just for a day on the South Beach on Allouette Lake. We got there nice and early (9:30am) so we could have ample parking and a good selection of a spot on the beach. It was nice to have the place to ourselves for a couple hours before it got very busy! Be sure to wake up really early and book your pass online because they go really fast! especially for the hiking!

Hikes are not so hard but some elevations can give you a good workout. Bring your horses and go for horse ride on the horse trails. Camping sites are currently closed but can be accessed by driving another 5 kms ahead. Beautiful, quiet spots. It can be little cold even on a hot summer day as the area is quite damp, so layer up!

Loved the outdoor adventures here. GOLDEN EARS IS AWESOME. Loved the trails, have easy to hard levelled trails for all hikers. Great views all around. So many things to do and see (hiking, camping, boating, beach etc). We tried lower falls trail which really easy and short but great views and waterfall is beautiful.

This is a beautiful place to go for easy and more advanced hikes. The space is vast. The views in every direction are spectacular. There are lakes and waterfalls to enjoy. The park entrance is not far from all the town's amenities. There's lots of parking and good signage throughout the park.
Day use passes required even if you aren't camping. They are freely available at discovercamping.ca from 6am for the same day.

279.text: The local hotspot for diving. I went to complete my open-water certification this weekend, onto a good start. Lots of wildlife, bald eagles, starfish and so much more. Nice drive out there too! Plenty places to walk around, various trails and a rock bridge out to an island to climb up. Get to it!  :)

Are many great Oceanside parks in and around Vancouver British Columbia but this is one of the best. Another one very close by is the one just east of lighthouse Park / point Atkinson. The name escape me at the moment. Because it is so popular, it can be very crowded on a terrific day . But if you pick a slightly off peak season day you will find yourself more or less alone spectacular seaside location.

Just a great west coast park with an awesome little trail and if you get low tide you can scurry over to the big rock! Bring good shoes (don't need to be hiking shoes, just good runners with grip) and enjoy the views! A family favorite :)

283.text: The mervelous sun set never expected.
Beautiful sunset, but the place is a little bit dirty and crowdy
The dirty sea but the place is nice

The burger was sloppy, but tasty.
The fries were great and plentiful.
Can be a bit crowned and noisy if you are looking for calm but nice place and a must stop for any visitor

290.text: I love this beautiful old theatre. I look forward to every visit. The ambiance is excellent, the sound is superb, and the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra always puts on a wonderful show. If you have long legs, take an aisle! The seats can be a bit tight if you’re plus sized and there isn’t a ton of leg room but the show is well worth it!  I always sit in the balcony, because I like the view from above the stage.
Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful! Fabulous location and staff that made our visit an excellent experience. Thank you Orpheum crew!
Such a beautiful theater. Watched Mark Knopfler perform last year and sat in the Dress Circle. Had a great view of the entire stage.

It was amazing to see my first love show here.
We sat up in the top area, third row and had a great show of the Wiggles.  At two years old my daughter had an amazing time. Sitting on my lap, we danced and sung along. Id recommend The Orpheum to anyone on Vancouver Island, such an experience.

Thank-you

The Orpheum is just a beautiful venue. The theatre is like something out of a movie, with the plush red carpet, brass bannisters, and ornate decorations, it’s just beautifully designed. There is also a lot of really cool history on display, including pictures of artists inducted into the B.C. Entertainment Hall of Fame. They also have plenty of concessions available though you meed to know to head upstairs as there is typically a longer lineup downstairs.

Being on the highest point of Vancouver, there are great city views to be had from the top of the park. There is also a restaurant which is open throughout the week.

His is a family friendly park to visit.  Plenty of parking, though we prefer to cycle - could do with more bike ranks near the conservatory.  Lots of trails to explore on foot.  There are a couple of naturalized areas which are a lot quieter.  He careful, outside of the dog off-leash area, many dog owners don't put their did back on a leash.  Tennis courts always seem busy.  To avoid crowds, head to naturalized area by rose garden/pitch n put, or to the duck pond area, away from the fantastic quarry gardens.

His place is so incredible. I cannot express enough how beautiful and serene this park is. Obviously the best time of year to go is in the summer time, during late July to early August. The landscaping in the botanical gardens is aesthetically pleasing and well maintained. The endless trails you can choose from to walk through the park make it the perfect place to go for a morning joy, a meditating walk or a first date. I have so many fond memories in Queen-E, it is a tireless tourist attraction and a local safe haven for anyone who appreciated flowers and nature. The best part is that it is FREE.

looks like maybe you can have fires on the beach. And the tide is one to be seen. I’ve never seen a tide go so far out

Talked out to the ocean today, about a km. from beach to water's shoreline at low tide. Weather was sunny and warm with a cooling breeze. Great family opportunity! Some people were swimming, as was a dog, and others were playing in the flats making sandcastles, skin boarding on the ponds, and beach coming. The views of the Vancouver skyline, mountains, surf, and ships awaiting entry into the harbour was spectacular. To toys required!

Talking the handy shoreline of Spanish Ranks, you suddenly realize this is the quintessential Vancouver experience; taking in the breathtaking skies, cool breeze, and panorama views of the city that surrounds you: West And, North and West Vancouver, as well as the misty islands that lie beyond, and probably go on forever. Any have come here before you, only to decide to make this cosmopolitan region the stage on which to build their livelihood and home. Languages from all over the world surround you as bits of finely woven conversations drift by, swiftly carried away on endless wind, leaving you to while away the hours, lost in thought, far out on the trembling tide flats, with one's best friend barking and splashing by your side. Marking fills up fast, so car pool if you can.

270.text: Lovely park and lake. The trails were nice and even so even I could walk them, despite my weak leg. There are one way signs all over to make it easier to avoid people, which is lovely for could and also just in general. Beautiful views and almost no garage. The air was also very crisp. I took a friend from Brazil around on a video tour and she loved it!

Love this gentle trail walk. It's good for beginners if you park downstairs and don't want inclines. You can go the whole way or stick to the right exit you'll find halfway. It'll be a wooden halfway. His takes you back to the beginning. Of you want it to be a little harder. Dark up on Sterling and walk up the stairs or the hidden Forest trail that takes a scene route. Check the maps for details and remember it's one way walk following the left side path due to could. Enjoy you walks!

Beer Take Dark is a beautiful place to escape the rustle and bustle of urban life in Burnaby. It's a lovely natural setting filled with views of the mountains, nature and sounds of singing birds. Excellent trails surrounding the lake and boat rental place near Western parking lot offers kayaks, canoe and paddle boats.
Great to have this park and lake except for goose excrement feeling the beach and picnic areas. Cross.

Beer Take Dark Festival Dawn is probably my favorite music venue in the Power Mainland. His outdoor  venue is in a beautiful tried setting overlooking a small lake. The lawn is beautifully maintained and always green even during the dry spells. KIDS: Children 10 years and under are free to attend with a supervising adult which gives it a nice family feel. Drinkers and kiss are notoriously absent minded and you'll want to pay attention that parties don't spill beer on your kiss. Even in summer, the grass gets damp in the evening... bring something to sit on.
GETTING THERE: The park easily accessible by car, public transit and close to the freely. There's plenty of free parking at the school for weekend and evening events and it's only a couple of blocks away from the venue. Traffic is usually managed effectively by the local police.
SMOKING: even though this area is deemed as non-smoking, you will find plenty of people lined up in certain areas smoking cigarettes and throughout the entire venue smoking a lot of marijuana. It's best to sit on the west side of the lawn (right side facing the stage) because the wind usually blows eastward and this will protect you from getting out too much smoke in your face.
WASHROOMS: Lots and lots of portable units specifically designate male and female. Normally I don't care whether I have a gender-specific mushroom, but when there's a lot of drinking and low light I do appreciate the effort to keep us girls clean.
DRINKING WATER: There's only one drinking station and it's at the back on the right hand (west) side near the mushrooms. You may bring an empty water bottle.
FOOD:  There is a limited selection of the usual event type food (and prices) for sale and lines can be long. To outside food is permitted. I recommend eating at home beforehand. Of you accidentally bring food, you can easily eat it outside the venue before you come in still listen to the music while you wait.
BERR: Yes there's beer! In plastic cups with a limit of two per person per purchase. To you can go back and get more if you can afford it.

290.text: I love this beautiful old theatre. I look forward to every visit. The alliance is excellent, the sound is superb, and the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra always puts on a wonderful show. Of you have long legs, take an aisle! The seats can be a bit tight if you’re plus sized and there isn’t a ton of leg room but the show is well worth it!  I always sit in the balcony, because I like the view from above the stage.

The Orpheum is just a beautiful venue. The theatre is like something out of a movie, with the plush red carpet, brass banister, and senate decorations, it’s just beautifully designed.
